title: In R.G. & G.R. Harris Funeral Homes Inc. v. EEOC, will the Supreme Court rule that the Civil Rights Act of 1964 prohibition against employment discrimination “because of…sex” encompasses discrimination based on transgender status?
preds: I can't remember a time when I was this happy to be completely wrong.

The reason the person was hired was not based on their curr bt sex,so changing it should not affect her job status. Regardless of the person's physical sex, legally a place of employment cannot terminate on those grounds.
Roberts will be the deciding vote, and will say that the termination was not due to sex, but to the transition from one to the other.
The recent reduction i’m rights afforded trans people in health care combined with a slightly right leaning court.

Although Trans people should be afforded the same protections of the Civil Rights act I do not believe that the court can rule in this case as it applies to this question as it would set a precedent for other current and hot button issues related to gender identity.  It can uphold the lower courts decision without addressing this particular question.
I don't feel that the makeup if there court and previous rights decisions will be favorable to transgender rights.
With all the appointed conservative judges and trump just stripping health benefits from transgender people, I don’t see this passing positively.

Based on the conservative majority on the Supreme Court and the fact that the current administration just stripped transgender of their medical rights, emphatically no. It is possible a charismatic attorney could make an impression on the court but not likely it would actually impact a negative outcome
With recent conservative appointments, unlikely a yes will come out.  Most likely is they will overturn the appellate court; followed by not taking the case.
The same reasoning that was applied in the reversal of the initial decision will likely hold at this level.

A person is born with a particular sex. Changing from male to female or vice versa does not actually change that. It hides it but does not change it. The procedure changes one’s gender. A conservative court will find a way to make this argument.
He majority will determine that the funeral home was within its rights to pick someone that the clients would be comfortable with in a smaller town where her transgender status would be well known
will not hand down decision in 2019 term
I believe I will be right

However, as the majority of supreme Court justices are Republican I wouldn't be to surprised if they apply their constitutional powers in the way that the founding fathers would have done. What was I thinking? At National Review, John Bursch argues that the court’s recent decision in Comcast v. National Association of African American-Owned Media, in which the court held that a plaintiff who sues for racial discrimination in contracting under federal law has to prove that race was a but-for cause of his injury, supports the employers’ position in R.G. & G.R. Harris Funeral Homes Inc. v. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, which asks whether federal employment discrimination law bars discrimination against transgender people
maintaining forecast. updating due to passage of time.

It ruled in the past that having to confirm to a sex stereotype is discrimination. Price Waterhouse v. Hopkins, 490 U.S. 228 (1989), was a landmark decision by the United States Supreme Court on the issues of prescriptive sex discrimination and employer liability for sex discrimination. The employee, Ann Hopkins, sued her former employer, the accounting firm Price Waterhouse. She argued that the firm denied her partnership because she didn't fit the partners' idea of what a female employee should look like and act like. The employer failed to prove that it would have denied her partnership anyway, and the Court held that constituted sex discrimination under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. 
The Caveat now is will they get this done in this term?
Lowering a tad. Court pretty conservative now.

Bumping my estimate down. I don't know much about this question, but I'm betting that a lot of the higher estimates are from people who want a positive answer. All of the evidence i see seems to support a lower estimate.

I am thinking that one of the conservatives will split the proverbial baby on the sex discrimination cases, deciding that Title VII's federal protection against discrimination "because of sex" would encompass sexual orientation but not transgender status. There was a hint of sympathy to the plaintiffs from Gorsuch during the consolidated oral arguments asking the advocate for the employer, why should someone be fired just because they happened to like someone of their own sex but later raised concerns for the great social upheaval that the court's decision may cause during the transgender case part of the arguments.

Downgrading from 15 to 5%.   Said more coherently than what was in my mind (matches my own logic): As the self-described radical feminists of the Women’s Liberation Front put it in their friend-of-the-court brief: “Legally redefining ‘female’ as anyone who claims to be female results in the erasure of female people as a class. If, as a matter of law, anyone can be a woman, then no one is a woman, and sex-based protections in the law have no meaning whatsoever . . . a ruling that Congress surely did not intend.” From:  https://nypost.com/2019/10/12/the-supreme-courts-new-sex-dilemma/?utm_source=reddit.com

Aimee Stephens (formerly known as Anthony Stephens) was born biologically male. While presenting as a man, Stephens worked as a funeral director at R.G. & G.R. Harris Funeral Homes, Inc. The funeral home owner and operator, Thomas Rost, terminated Stephens' employment after Stephens informed him she would transition from male to female and dress as a woman at work. Stephens filed a complaint with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC).[4] After investigating Stephens' claims, the EEOC charged the funeral home with violating Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by (1) ending Stephens' employment on the basis of gender and (2) administering a discriminatory dress code policy.[4] The district court granted summary judgment to the funeral home, which argued (1) the funeral home's dress code did not violate Title VII, (2) enforcing Title VII and requiring the home to employ Stephens would constitute an unjustified substantial burden on Rost's religious beliefs, and (3) the EEOC could not bring a claim against the home's clothing allowance because the home "could not reasonably expect a clothing-allowance claim to emerge from an investigation into Stephens's termination."[4] On appeal, the 6th Circuit reversed the district court's summary judgment, granted summary judgment to the EEOC, and remanded the case to the district court.[4]
I predict that SCOTUS will succeed in "Breaking" the word SEX into meaningless letters.

I'm going to go with a low estimate here based on the idea that this is a polarizing issue and many people will vote high or low based on personal opinion rather than on probabilities.  There are many interesting comments below arguing for high or low estimates. The most interesting to me is by @chrisp which I reproduce here because they are buried in replies to a comment: 
"The EEOC (under Obama) filed against the employer.
The employer won a summary judgement (essentially, saying there is no case here).
The EEOC appealed to the 6th circuit, which in Mar 2018 was 10-6 democrats, one of the most liberal courts in the country.
The liberal appeal court overturned, and then the employer appealed to the Supreme Court. The issue[s] at stake [are]:
Does title VII of the Civil Rights act of 1964 (meant to prohibit discrimination on a basis of sex) prevent the firing of someone who identifies as transgender. Alternately, does Waterhouse v. Hopkins which prevents the stereotyping of individuals apply.
The third relevant issue is - "Is the clear and convincing standard" the appropriate legal standard - is it reasonable bar?
Fourth, and most relevant. Under statute, the prevailing standard is can the company demonstrate that absent questions of sex, would the company have fired the individual anyway. ... ***The federal government (EEOC) now agrees that Harris did not conduct sex discrimination***"

Flipping - I believe the SC will rule that sex is not the same definition as sexual orientation since sex (meaning gender) is biological/scientifically defined.  Being a transgender does not biologically change DNA to the opposite gender.  There are occupational roles where it is warranted that the candidate be a verifiable man or woman and not a transgender. Ergo, the SC would likely prefer to see legislation create a new legal definition and not themselves.   If Ginsburg has to step down without hearing the case, it makes it even more likely the SC will overturn the Circuit ruling.

The 4 liberal justices will agree this is discriminatory, won't take much for at least one of the conservative justices (guess: Kennedy) to agree that the Civil Rights Act could not have predicted  the concept of gender identity and will determine that sex discrimination includes gender identity discrimination.  Truly religious outfits will  still not necessarily be inflicted as they can still hire based on the practicing religion of their employees and if they adhere to those tenants.

When title 7 was enacted transgender was not an thing and homosexuality was criminal in some states.  I think the conservative majority will cite this fact as basis for not including sex orientation in title 7 protection.

Kavanaugh has already rules against this, it turns out. Leaving it 4-3 in favor of mr. Stephens, with gorsuch and Roberts. I'm all in on zero but I rate the chances at 40 for those wanting an accurate assessment
Not the intent of Congress in 1964

I think this one is an easier call.  Discrimination based on gender is a violation of the law.  A conservative circuit court upheld the complaint, so it is the employer who is filing here.  I expect the Supreme Court to accept that the gender of transgender people, however construed, should not be a basis for termination.
